content:
1. Analyze each scenario:

For each causal graph scenario, create a causal model, identify the causal effect, estimate the causal effect, and interpret the results. Comparing the results across different scenarios can help you assess the robustness of your findings and validate your assumptions.
```python
# Helper function for analysis
def analyze_scenario(data, causal_graph):
    model = CausalModel(data=data,
                        treatment=["Exercise", "SocialSupport", "Sleep", "SelfImprovement"],
                        outcome="ResilienceIndex",
                        graph=causal_graph)
    identified_estimand = model.identify_effect()
    causal_estimate = model.estimate_effect(identified_estimand, method_name="backdoor.linear_regression")
    print("Causal Effects:\n", causal_estimate)
    return causal_estimate

# Analyze each scenario
print("\nScenario 1:")
estimate_scenario1 = analyze_scenario(data, causal_graph_scenario1)

print("\nScenario 2:")
estimate_scenario2 = analyze_scenario(data, causal_graph_scenario2)

print("\nScenario 3:")
estimate_scenario3 = analyze_scenario(data, causal_graph_scenario3)
```
Running this code will output the causal effects for each scenario, allowing you to compare the results and assess the impact of different assumptions on the estimated causal effects. By testing multiple scenarios, you can validate the robustness of your findings and develop a better understanding of the relationships between the variables in your dataset.
